boat.construction_details: Elm Keel, oak frames. Carvel larch and pine planks

for_sales.sales_text:
Length 28" 6' Beam 10" 3' Draft 4" 6'. Gaff topsail cutter rig with topmast. Sails good condition some new. All terylene except for topsail. Hull pitch pine/larch/elm planks on grown oak frames. Planking 1 5/16' thick. Frames 2 1/4' sided moulded 5' at keel, 2 1/4' at the timber heads, spaced at 12' centres, most doubled (futtocks) from new. All fastenings are bronze including keel bolts for the lead keel. Decks are Brunzeel ply 3/4' thick epoxy sheathed.

Very spacious interior much as it was when she was converted in 1948. Two saloon berths, two more in the fo"c"sle, heads, very large pantry, navigation area opposite galley. Rebuilt Lister STW engine gives a cruising speed of 5.5 to 6 knots. Very economical.

"Margaret" is a very stiff boat and easy to sail. Top mast has been removed but still available. She has been continually upgraded and refurbished in traditional and authentic materials since 2003 to keep her sailing. A new custodian is sought to keep "Margaret" on the water, to enjoy further adventures.

boat.full_description:
Launched as the 'Eureka' in 1911, and registered for fishing 25 November 1911, tonnage 10.8 and fishing no. PE62. She is believed to be the last of the larger Poole smacks.

'Margaret Catchpole' was well known on the East Coast having been kept at Pin Mill on the River Orwell for 50 years and subsequently on the River Medway at Lower Upnor since 2003.

'Margaret' is a very stiff boat and easy to sail. She has been continually upgraded and refurbished in traditional and authentic materials since 2003 to keep her sailing.

In 2016, she was sold following the death of her owner.
boat.name: Margaret Catchpole
boat.short_description: Now believed to be lost / broken up in the Medwat around 2017. Built in Poole as a fishing smack, and converted to a yacht in 1947 at Christchurch, 'Margaret Catchpole' was kept at Pin Mill until 2003 when she was moved to Rochester.
